newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan stocks close up despite profit-taking.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan stocks close up despite profit-taking.

text.p: Taiwan share prices closed slightly higher on Tuesday despite late profit-taking, but brokers expected a consolidation to continue.
The weighted index closed 24.84 points or 0.30 percent higher at 8,294.27. Turnover was T$77.6 billion, well below recent levels that were in excess of T$100 billion.
Brokers said Wall Street's overnight rise helped sentiment but was not a big incentive to fuel buying.
"It is encouraging to see Wall Street's gains, but the market is still largely dominated by domestic factors," said Albert Lin, research head of Golden Securities.
Some brokers described the market as in a "vacuum period" as investors were still looking for new investment targets after dumping shares they believed were over-valued.
Fears over worsening social disorder and political instability also deterred buying interest, brokers said.
"People are not willing to take the risk and increase their stock portfolio amid the uncertainties," Lin said.

Shocked by the murder of a famous actress's teenage daughter, more than 50,000 people demonstrated on Sunday to demand the resignation of Premier Lien Chan and a cabinet reshuffle to take responsibility for rising crime.
Electronics shares suffered early selling after a 20-minute power outage in Taiwan's Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park on Monday shut down operations at many electronic firms.
United Microelectronics fell 50 cents to T$66. But the island's leading chipmaker Taiwan Semiconductor recovered from early setbacks to gain T$1.50 or 1.56 percent to T$97.50.
Taiwan's First International Computer Inc was up T$1 or 1.28 percent to T$79 after Lehman Brothers, the global investment bank, said it had initiated coverage on the firm with a "1-buy" rating.
